sentences.text: The '''2024 Washington summit''' was the NATO summit|33rd summit of the heads of state and heads of government|government of the thirty-two members of the NATO|North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), their partner countries and the European Union (EU), which took place in Washington, D.C., United States, on 9–11 July 2024. The summit commemorates the landmark 75th anniversary of NATO, which was founded on 4 April 1949 with the signing of the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington, DC. The summit was also the fourth NATO summit to be held in the United States following the 1978 Washington summit, 1999 Washington summit and 2012 Chicago summit. It also marks the first summit since Sweden–NATO relations|Sweden acceded to NATO and the last for Jens Stoltenberg as Secretary General of NATO|Secretary General.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |title=NATO summits |url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_50115.htm |website=nato.int |publisher=NATO}}</ref>

sentences.text: The official title of the 2024 Washington summit is "Ukraine and transatlantic security." It is meant to highlight the focus on NATO's response to escalating global threats to peace and democracies, with particular attention to Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine and North Korea's involvement on the side of Russia through weapon supply and troop deployment to the Ukrainian front lines. Following the announcement of North Korea–Russia relations#Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian and North Korean cooperation agreements, Stoltenberg stated that Ukraine-South Korea cooperation would be discussed at the summit. The alliance is also set to discuss perceived threats posed by China and the security situation in the Indo-Pacific region. Additionally, agenda includes dialog on boosting defence production and reaffirming allies' commitment to military readiness and the defence of all of NATO's territory.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/event/nato-summit-ukraine-and-transatlantic-security/|title=The Washington NATO Summit: Ukraine and transatlantic security|date=21 May 2024|website=atlanticcouncil.org|publisher=Atlantic Council}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/13/us/politics/north-korea-weapons-russia-ukraine.html|title=North Korea Shipped Arms to Russia for Use in Ukraine, U.S. Says|first=Peter|last=Baker|date=13 October 2023|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref>

sentences.text: At an Atlantic Council event, US permanent representative to NATO Julianne Smith indicated that NATO was not ready to extend a formal invitation to Ukraine for membership during the 2023 Vilnius summit|previous year's summit in Vilnius and is unlikely to do so at the upcoming Washington summit. Instead, she expects NATO allies to provide Ukraine with a "deliverable" that would bring the country closer to membership, focusing on institutionalizing the bilateral support that has grown over the past two years. While details on this deliverable remain unclear, Smith emphasized NATO's ongoing commitment to Ukraine through measures like the NATO-Ukraine Council, established at the 2023 NATO summit.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/new-atlanticist/expect-a-new-bridge-to-nato-membership-for-ukraine-at-the-washington-summit-says-julianne-smith/|title=Expect a new 'bridge' to NATO membership for Ukraine at the Washington summit, says Julianne Smith|website=www.atlanticcouncil.org|date=29 April 2024 |publisher=Atlantic Council}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 27 June 2024, the President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy visited NATO Headquarters, where NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed him to discuss the final preparations for the Washington Summit. Stoltenberg stated that he expects NATO Allies to agree on NATO taking the lead in the coordination and provision of security assistance and training for Ukraine. He also proposed a long-term financial pledge to provide Ukraine with greater predictability in the support it receives.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_227133.htm|title=Secretary General welcomes President Zelenskyy to NATO Headquarters to prepare Washington Summit|author=|date=27 June 2024|website=nato.int|publisher=NATO}}</ref>

sentences.text: A week before the summit, NATO Director of Policy Planning, Benedetta Berti, anticipated new commitments to invest in the "deterrence and defense architecture" of the alliance, a greater role in training and assistance for Ukraine, as well as a restatement to eventually add Ukraine into NATO, and stronger ties with Japan, Australia, the Republic of Korea, and New Zealand.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Landgraf |first=Rick |date=July 2, 2024 |title=In Conversation with Benedetta Berti |url=https://www.fpri.org/article/2024/07/in-conversation-with-benedetta-berti-an-inside-look-at-nato-policy-planning/ |website=Foreign Policy Research Institute}}</ref>

sentences.text: Despite a Mobilization in Ukraine#2024|controversial mobilization law passed in 2024, which lowered the mobilization age from 27 to 25, Ukraine still faces a severe manpower shortage. With a population of 144 million people, Russia significantly outnumbered Ukraine's 38 million in 2022. This demographic advantage gives Russia greater manpower resources. However, Casualties of the Russo-Ukrainian War#Total casualties|Russian losses in the war are generally considered higher than Ukraine's. Both have lost significant amounts of personnel, though no precise numbers can be given until after the invasion and when all cases are investigated.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ukraine-mobilization-law-1.7208625|title=Ukraine's mobilization law now in force, sparking fears more essential workers will be drafted|first=|last=|date=18 May 2024|newspaper=CBC News}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 14 May 2024, United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived to Kyiv announced to reaffirm the support of his country, less than a month after Congress approved a $60 billion aid package. With expedited delivery of military assistance, including artillery and air defence systems, the trip underscored the Biden administration's commitment to Ukraine's long-term security amidst escalating conflict. Blinken stated, "We are with you today. And we will stay by your side until Ukraine's security, sovereignty, its ability to choose its own path is guaranteed."

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/04/23/politics/senate-vote-foreign-aid/index.html|title=Senate passes $95 billion package sending aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan after months of delay|first1=Morgan|last1=Rimmer|first2=Ted|last2=Barrett|date=30 April 2024|newspaper=CNN}}</ref>

sentences.text: On the morning of 24 May, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán said in a broadcast on Magyar Rádió that his government planned to redefine Hungary's NATO membership "without taking part in NATO operations outside NATO territory" due to his stance on foreign aid to Ukraine. Orbán is the only leader of any EU and NATO member state who, despite united efforts by both blocs to support Ukraine economically, militarily and politically, continues to maintain close ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Earlier in January, the EU threatened to impose voting sanctions on Hungary and permanently cut off its funding if Orbán's government continued to veto a €50 billion (approximately US$54 billion) aid package for Ukraine. This resulted in Hungary dropping its veto and a successful EU agreement on such aid.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/hungary-will-opt-out-nato-ukraine-operations-7487a597739f92075a6efa72e0ca3fed#:~:text=BUDAPEST%2C%20Hungary%20(AP)%20—,more%20direct%20conflict%20with%20Russia.|title=Hungary will seek to opt out of NATO efforts to support Ukraine, Orbán says|first=Justin|last=Spike|date=24 May 2024|newspaper=AP News}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 27 June 2024, Ukraine and EU signed a historic security deal, which set out the commitment of all 27 member states to aid Ukraine with extensive support, regardless of any internal institutional changes, according to the Ukrainian President Zelenskyy. On the same day 2 similar deals were signed with Lithuania and Estonia. Ukraine has already signed 19 similar bilateral security agreements, including with the United States, France and the UK. These agreements, while not mutual defence pacts, signify strategic partnerships aimed at bolstering Ukraine's stability and security amidst ongoing regional challenges.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-eu-leaders-sign-security-deal-with-ukraine-discuss-defence-and-top/|title=EU leaders sign security deal with Ukraine, discuss defence and top posts|first1=Julia|last1=Payne|first2=Thomas|last2=Escritt|date=27 June 2024|newspaper=The Globe and Mail}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.france24.com/en/europe/20240627-eu-ukraine-security-agreement-will-advance-peace-says-zelensky|title=EU-Ukraine security agreement will advance 'peace', says Zelensky|first=|last=|date=27 June 2024|newspaper=France24}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|Russia–NATO relations}}
On 24 May 2024, the State Department announced that Secretary of State Antony Blinken would visit Eastern Europe amidst escalating concerns over Russia's advances in Ukraine as it opened a new northern front with an attack on the Kharkiv region, potential Russian interference in Moldova, and 2023–2024 Georgian protests|Georgian protests against a proposed "foreign agent" bill similar to Russian foreign agent law|that adopted in Russia. Blinken visited Chişinau on 29 May and Prague on 30 and 31 May. He met Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavský and other officials to deliberate on support for Ukraine, alongside the Georgian "foreign agent" bill.

sentences.text: On 3 May, during a visit to Kyiv, UK Foreign Secretary David Cameron said that Ukraine had the decision as to how it would use British weapons and the right to strike with them inside Russia. This was a major policy change on the part of the United Kingdom, a List of states with nuclear weapons#United Kingdom|nuclear state and key NATO member. Kremlin Press Secretary Dmitry Peskov and the spokeswoman for Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs Maria Zakharova condemned the decision. On 29 May, representatives of Finland, Canada and Poland issued separate statements saying that Ukraine can strike Legitimate military target|valid military targets inside Russia using their weapons.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c163kp93l6po|title=Kyiv can use British weapons inside Russia - Cameron|first=Paul|last=Kirby|date=3 May 2024|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/kremlin-calls-cameron-statement-uk-arms-ukraine-direct-escalation-2024-05-03/|title=Kremlin calls Cameron statement on UK arms for Ukraine a 'direct escalation'|first=|last=|date=3 May 2024|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kyivindependent.com/finland-canada/|title=Finland, Canada, Poland don't prohibit Ukraine from striking targets in Russia with their weapons|first=Kateryna|last=Denisova|date=29 May 2024|newspaper=The Kyiv Independent}}</ref>

sentences.text: By the end of May, several leaders had also endorsed lifting the concurrent ban on Western-supplied weapons, including presidents Emmanuel Macron of France, Edgars Rinkēvičs of Latvia and Alar Karis of Estonia; German Chancellor Olaf Scholz; and prime ministers Alexander De Croo of Belgium, Petr Fiala of the Czech Republic and Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, as well as the foreign ministers of Canada, Lithuania, Norway, the United Kingdom and Poland; and the defence ministers of Finland, the Netherlands and Sweden. Conversely, Belgium and Italy were against the use of Western-supplied weapons by Ukraine to strike targets within Russia.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Hrudka |first=Orysia |date=31 May 2024 |title=Most allies now support Ukraine striking targets in Russia; Italy and Belgium oppose, US undecided |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2024/05/31/most-allies-now-support-ukraine-striking-targets-in-russia-italy-and-belgium-oppose-us-undecided/ |newspaper=Euromaidan Press}}</ref>

<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Denisova |first=Kateryna |date=29 May 2024 |title=Ukraine urges allies to lift Western arms ban on hitting targets inside Russia. Will they? |url=https://kyivindependent.com/ukraine-urges-allies-to-lift-western-arms-ban-on-hitting-targets-inside-russia-will-they/ |access-date= |newspaper=The Kyiv Independent}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 30 May, US President Joe Biden implicitly gave Ukraine permission to strike inside Russia, but only near the Kharkiv Oblast, with no exact borderlines defined. The decision came after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other officials urged their allies to allow Ukraine to strike inside Russia with Western-supplied weapons in response to the daily bombings of Ukrainian cities by Russian forces from military bases located inside Russia. This came with a "just over the border" striking policy limited to Kharkiv Oblast, where Russia launched an offensive and made tactical gains.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2024/05/30/biden-ukraine-weapons-strike-russia-00160731|title=Biden secretly gave Ukraine permission to strike inside Russia with US weapons|first1=Erin|last1=Banco|first2=Alexander|last2=Ward|first3=Lara|last3=Seligman|date=30 May 2024|newspaper=Politico}}</ref>

<ref name=":0" /> Shortly after the US lifted these restrictions, the German government gave permission for Ukraine to use its weapons inside Russia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/germany-says-ukraine-can-use-its-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-u-s-also-eases-its-stance|title=Germany says Ukraine can use its weapons against targets in Russia after the U.S. also eases its stance|first1=Illia|last1=Novikov|first2=Matthew|last2=Lee|first3=Karel|last3=Janicek|date=31 May 2024|newspaper=PBS News Hour}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dw.com/en/ukraine-updates-russia-making-tactical-gains-in-kharkiv/live-69065078|title=Ukraine updates: Russia making 'tactical' gains in Kharkiv|first=|last=|date=13 May 2024|newspaper=Deutsche Welle}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 20 June 2024, facing pressure from Ukraine and its European allies, and in response to the North Korea-Russia mutual defence pact, the United States authorised Ukraine to use American-supplied weapons against Russian forces across the border, extending beyond the region near Kharkiv. This decision facilitated successful Ukrainian military operations that included strikes into Russian territory. Ukrainian officials have subsequently advocated for the lifting of restrictions on long-range missile systems such as the ATACMS, which Ukraine was currently not allowed to use on Russian territory.

sentences.text: On 19 June 2024, North Korea and Russia signed a mutual defence agreement during Vladimir Putin's first visit to Pyongyang in 24 years. This event has been marked as a major escalation of tensions on the Korean Peninsula. In response, South Korea summoned Russian Ambassador Georgy Zinoviev to protest the deal. On 20 June, South Korean national security adviser Chang Ho-jin stated, "We will reconsider the issue of supplying weapons to Ukraine." This statement was also marked an unprecedented change in South Korea's strict military doctrine, which traditionally prohibits sending arms to countries engaged in active military conflicts. Putin warned that it would be a "big mistake" if South Korea arms Ukraine.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/putin-kim-agree-develop-strategic-fortress-relations-kcna-says-2024-06-18/|title=Russia's Putin and North Korea's Kim sign a mutual defence pact|first1=Josh|last1=Smith|first2=Ju-min|last2=Park|date=19 June 2024|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/19/russia-and-north-korea-sign-mutual-defence-pact|title=Russia and North Korea sign mutual defence pact|first1=Justin|last1=McCurry|first2=Andrew|last2=Roth|date=19 June 2024|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>

|first=Kim|last=Tong-Hyung|date=21 June 2024|newspaper=AP News}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/34439f7d-e546-40eb-92e5-54aa0224ecbe|title=South Korea to consider supplying arms to Ukraine after Putin-Kim pact|first=Song|last=Jung-a|date=21 June 2024|newspaper=Financial Times}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/south-korea-will-consider-supplying-arms-to-ukraine-after-russia-north-korea-sign-strategic-pact/7676277.html#|title=South Korea will consider supplying arms to Ukraine after Russia, North Korea sign strategic pact|first=|last=|date=27 June 2024|newspaper=Voice of America}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/south-korea-says-will-reconsider-providing-weapons-ukraine-yonhap-says-2024-06-20/|title=South Korea to reconsider providing weapons to Ukraine|first=|last=|date=20 June 2024|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c1ee8x221lno|title=Putin warns South Korea against arming Ukraine|first=Kelly|last=Ng|date=20 June 2024|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/sending-weapons-to-ukraine-would-be-a-big-mistake-putin-warns-south-korea/|title=Putin warns South Korea: Sending killer weapons to Ukraine would be a 'big mistake'|first=Seb|last=Starcevic|date=20 June 2024|newspaper=Politico}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 17 June, while visiting President Biden in Washington, D.C. ahead of the summit, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg announced that a record 23 of 32 NATO member states were meeting their defence spending targets of 2% of their country's GDP. According to NATO, defence spending for European member states and Canada was up 18%.<ref name="NATOSpending" /><ref name="APSpending"/>

references.text: <ref name="NATOSpending">{{cite web|title=Secretary General in Washington: NATO makes America stronger|url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_226749.htm?selectedLocale=en|website=nato.int|publisher=NATO|date=17 June 2024|access-date=19 June 2024}}</ref>

<ref name="APSpending">{{cite web|title=A record number of NATO allies are hitting their defense spending target during war in Ukraine|url=https://apnews.com/article/nato-defense-spending-stoltenberg-biden-5246409eec70745e6e936d997073a6f4|author1=Knickmeyer, Ellen|author2=Seung Min Kim|publisher=Associated Press|website=APNews.com|date=17 June 2024|access-date=19 June 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text:
Several Eastern members of the block have pushed for higher military budgets. Poland's President Andrzej Duda called on NATO countries to urgently increase spending to 3% of their GDP. Poland is expected to and committed to allocating more than 4% of its GDP on defence in 2024, which would surpass other countries spending by a significant margin, while the Baltic states have jointly committed to invest at least 2.5% of GDP in defence.
 with outgoing NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg]]
The UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer urged NATO members to increase defence spending further, aligning with his plans for the UK to allocate tens of billions of pounds extra to military budget in response to growing global threats faced by alliance members. Starmer also committed the United Kingdom to raising defence spending to 2.5%, though did not indicate when it would be raised. On the flight to the summit, Starmer reiterated his "cast iron commitment" to spending 2.5%. Starmer stated he will lay out a "road map", following a “root and branch” review of the country's defences, which officials said will include a concrete date to hit the spending target.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/polish-president-says-nato-members-should-spend-3-gdp-defence-2024-03-11/|title=Polish president says NATO members should spend 3% of GDP on defence|first=|last=|date=11 March 2024|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2024/03/19/russia-ukraine-poland-says-nato-must-urgently-ramp-spending.html#:~:text=Polish%20President%20Andrzej%20Duda%20said,alliance%20within%20the%20coming%20years|title='Alarm bells are ringing': Poland's president says NATO must urgently ramp up defense spending|first=Karen|last=Gilchrist|date=19 March 2024|newspaper=CNBC News}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/polands-2024-budget-see-big-spending-defence-social-benefits-2023-08-24/|title=Poland's 2024 budget to see big spending on defence, social benefits|first=|last=|date=24 August 2023|newspaper=Reuters}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nato.int/nato_static_fl2014/assets/pdf/2024/6/pdf/240617-def-exp-2024-en.pdf|title=Defence Expenditure of NATO Countries (2014-2024)|author=|access-date=12 June 2024|website=nato.int|publisher=NATO}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kyivindependent.com/baltic-countries-to-push-for-2-5-gdp-defense-spending-during-nato-summit/|title=Baltic countries to push for 2.5% of GDP defense spending minimum during NATO summit|first=Martin|last=Fornusek|date=23 May 2024|newspaper=The Kyiv Independent}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article/2024/jul/09/keir-starmer-nato-summit-defence-spending|title=Starmer to urge Nato members to boost defence spending amid UK review|first=Pippa|last=Grerar|date=8 July 2024|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/uk-keir-starmer-prime-minister-nato-members-summit-us-elections-defense-spending/|title=UK's Keir Starmer urges allies to hike defense spending|first=Stefan|last=Boscia|date=9 July 2024|newspaper=Politico}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|last=Lawless|first=Jill|url=https://apnews.com/article/keir-starmer-labour-challenges-ukraine-nato-gaza-0da1da8a74c6196518059d7d9fbcf77d|title=PM says defence spending commitment 'cast iron'|date=6 July 2024|website=Associated Press|access-date=7 July 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240706052701/https://apnews.com/article/keir-starmer-labour-challenges-ukraine-nato-gaza-0da1da8a74c6196518059d7d9fbcf77d|archive-date=6 July 2024|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Fisher|first1=Lucy|last2=Foy|first2=Henry|url=https://www.ft.com/content/cdaaab5e-eead-47ce-890c-cf66473b7a82|title=Starmer plans 'road map' for UK to hit higher defence spending goal|date=9 July 2024|website=Financial Times|url-access=subscription|access-date=9 July 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240709224227/https://www.ft.com/content/cdaaab5e-eead-47ce-890c-cf66473b7a82|archive-date=9 July 2024|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|Ukraine–NATO relations|NATO–Ukraine Council}}

Leaders such as Biden supported the Ukraine Compact.

references.text: <ref name="pbs1">{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JPLrtFMB928 | title=WATCH LIVE: Biden hosts Ukraine Compact event with allies and partner countries at NATO summit }}</ref>
<ref name="bbg1">{{cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/shorts/F0GRXrgff9g?app=desktop | title=Biden at NATO Summit Unveils Ukraine Compact to Deter Putin }}</ref>

<ref name="cspan1">{{cite news |title=President Biden Remarks on the Ukraine Compact at NATO Summit|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?536940-1/president-biden-remarks-ukraine-compact-nato-summit}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Orange Revolution in Ukraine in 2004, which nullified the election of pro-Russian presidential candidate Viktor Yanukovych, still did not reflect on public opinion with a significant vote of 60% against joining NATO.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archive.kyivpost.com/article/content/eu-ukraine-relations/poll-almost-half-of-ukrainians-back-ukraines-accession-to-eu-318650.html|title= Poll: Almost half of Ukrainians back Ukraine's accession to EU|author=Interfax-Ukraine|date=10 January 2013|newspaper=Kyiv Post}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2013/01/10/6981191/view_print/|title=Almost half of Ukrainians want to join the EU, slightly less want to join the Customs Union|date=10 January 2013|newspaper=Ukrainska Pravda}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Russian annexation of Crimea and 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest in 2014, Ukrainian support for NATO membership has been growing gradually. After the 2022 invasion, public stances on membership significantly changed from a relatively low 59.2% in favour and 28.1% against in 2021 to a resounding 89% in favour by May 2023. Subsequently, the rate stabilized at 77% in favour and 5% against by 2024.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kiis.com.ua/?lang=ukr&cat=reports&id=1083&page=1|title=Attitude to the access of Ukraine to the EU and NATO, attitude to direct negotiations with v. putin, and perception of the military threat from Russia: results of the telephone survey conducted december 13-16, 2021|publisher=KIV INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTE SOCIOLOGY}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ratinggroup.ua/files/ratinggroup/reg_files/ukr_february_2024_national_survey_public.pdf|title=All UKRAINIAN Survey|author=<!-- Not stated -->|website=ratinggroup.ua|publisher=Center for insights in survey research}}</ref>

sentences.text: NATO officially highlights support for Ukraine is unwavering, with the alliance determined to stand by Ukraine indefinitely. This stance is meant to send a strong message to Russia that NATO allies remain united and committed to help Ukraine fight off Russia's illegal invasion.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/blinken-no-fatigue-in-nato-support-of-ukraine-/7376980.html|title=Blinken: 'No Fatigue' in NATO Support of Ukraine|date=29 November 2024|first=Nike|last=Ching|newspaper=Voice of America}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/topics_192648.htm#:~:text=The%20Alliance%20fully%20supports%20Ukraine's,most%20substantial%20of%20NATO's%20partnerships.|title=NATO's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine|date=21 March 2024|website=nato.int|publisher=NATO}}</ref>

sentences.text:
Although some NATO members, particularly those in Eastern Europe, pushed for Ukrainian accession to the alliance, they considered it to not be possible before the invasion ends due to the implication that NATO could be considered to be directly involved in the Russo-Ukrainian War|war with Russia if Ukraine were already made a member.
 (left) in Washington, D.C., July 11, 2024]]

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://carnegieendowment.org/research/2023/10/ukraines-accession-poses-a-unique-conundrum-for-the-eu?lang=en|title=Ukraine's Accession Poses a Unique Conundrum for the EU|first1=Sophia|last1=Besch|first2=Eric|last2=Ciaramella|date=24 October 2024|website=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace|publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2024/04/5/7449860/|title=Ukraine won't be invited to NATO at Washington summit in order not to bring NATO into war – NYT|first1=Ivanna|last1=Kostina|first2=Stanislav|last2=Pohorilov|date=5 April 2024|newspaper=Ukrainska Pravda}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|United States support for Israel in the Israel–Hamas war|British support for Israel in the Israel–Hamas war}}
Speaking at the Washington summit, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez urged NATO members to avoid "double standards" regarding the Israel–Hamas war|wars in Gaza and Ukraine, saying, "If we demand respect for international law in Ukraine, we must demand it in Gaza as well."<ref name="aljazeera-summit"/>

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=Spanish PM: NATO must avoid 'double standards' over Gaza, Ukraine |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/program/newsfeed/2024/7/11/spanish-pm-nato-must-avoid-double-standards-over-gaza-ukraine |work=Al Jazeera |date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: In his speech, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan said that NATO values are being trampled by Israel in the Gaza Strip.

references.text: <ref name="aljazeera-summit">{{cite news |title=What has NATO promised Ukraine – and did Gaza figure in summit talks? |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/11/what-has-nato-promised-ukraine-at-summit-and-did-gaza-figure-in-talks |work=Al Jazeera |date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{See also|Armenia–Azerbaijan relations}}
The foreign ministers of Armenia and Azerbaijan and U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken held a trilateral meeting on the sidelines of the summit. Armenia and Azerbaijan have made considerable progress towards finalizing a peace agreement following the Armenia–Azerbaijan border crisis (2021–present)|border crisis and the 2023 Azerbaijani offensive in Nagorno-Karabakh. Blinken stated, "Today is an opportunity to take stock in the progress that's been made, what remains. But based on all of the engagements that we've had, including in recent weeks, I believe both countries are very close to being able to reach a final agreement, one that the United States would strongly, strongly support."

references.text: <ref>[https://armenianweekly.com/2024/07/10/armenia-azerbaijan-and-us-hold-trilateral-meeting-in-washington-amid-nato-summit/ Armenia, Azerbaijan and US hold trilateral meeting in Washington amid NATO summit]</ref>

<ref name=thehill/> During the reception, United States President Joe Biden presented outgoing NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg with the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest Civilian decorations of the United States|civilian award of the United States.<ref name=thehill>{{cite news |first=Laura |last=Kelly |title=Biden presents NATO chief with Presidential Medal of Freedom |url=https://thehill.com/policy/defense/4763036-biden-medal-freedom-stoltenberg-nato-summit/ |work=The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill |publisher= |date=2024-07-09 |access-date=2024-07-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240710020505/https://thehill.com/policy/defense/4763036-biden-medal-freedom-stoltenberg-nato-summit/ |archive-date=2024-07-10 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On the first day of the summit on July 9, 2024, US President Joe Biden accused Russian President Vladimir Putin of wanting to erase "Ukraine off the map". He announced that several NATO nations including the United States, the Netherlands, Germany, Italy, and Romania would provide Ukraine with equipment for five air defense systems. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned that action in Ukraine needed to be conducted prior to the 2024 United States presidential election|U.S. presidential election in November 2024 to limit the impact of decisions Donald Trump might take, if he were elected president, to reduce support for NATO and Ukraine.

references.text: <ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last1=Stepansky |first1=Joseph |last2=Marsi |first2=Federica |date=10 July 2024 |title=NATO countries pledge long-term support for Ukraine as allies meet |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/liveblog/2024/7/10/nato-summit-washington-live |access-date=2024-07-11 |website=Al Jazeera |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: The United States announced its intention to deploy Ballistic missiles|long-range missiles in Germany from 2026. US weapons in Germany would include RIM-174 Standard ERAM|SM-6 and Tomahawk (missile family)|Tomahawk cruise missiles and Long-Range Hypersonic Weapon|hypersonic weapons. The United States' decision to deploy missiles in Germany has been compared to the deployment of Pershing II launchers in Western Europe in the 1980s. The decision was supported by German Chancellor Olaf Scholz.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |title=A new arms race in Europe? US long-range weapons in Germany |url=https://www.dw.com/en/a-new-arms-race-in-europe-us-long-range-weapons-in-germany/a-69648733 |work=Deutsche Welle |date=13 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Germany’s Scholz under friendly fire over US missile plan |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/olaf-scholz-germany-american-long-range-missiles-social-democratic-party-bundestag-russia/ |work=Politico |date=31 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Putin warns US against deploying long-range missiles in Germany |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/28/putin-warns-us-against-deploying-long-range-missiles-in-germany |work=The Guardian |date=28 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Russia says US missiles in Germany signal return of Cold War |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/11/russia-says-us-missiles-in-germany-signal-return-of-cold-war |work=Al Jazeera |date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |title=Germany split on US stationing long-range cruise missiles |url=https://www.dw.com/en/germany-split-on-us-stationing-long-range-cruise-missiles/a-69638145 |work=Deutsche Welle |date=11 July 2024}}</ref>

references.text: <ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.csis.org/analysis/what-will-happen-natos-washington-summit#:~:text=Current%20secretary%20general%20Stoltenberg%20will,Dutch%20secretary%20general%20Joseph%20Luns.|title=What Will Happen at NATO's Washington Summit|date=2 July 2024|website=csis.org|publisher=Center for Strategic and International Studies |last1=Monaghan |first1=Sean |last2=Martinez |first2=Sissy |last3=Palazzi |first3=Andrea Leonard |last4=Svendsen |first4=Otto }}</ref>
